I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2003 Country Programming Mission, the Government of Indonesia requested 
project preparatory technical assistance (TA) for the productivity enhancement for tree crops 
project,  to  invigorate  the  smallholder  tree-crop  subsector  and  increase  the  incomes  of 
smallholder tree-crop farmers, reduce poverty, and increase the contribution of tree crops to the 
national economy. The Fact-Finding Mission visited Indonesia in July 2003 to develop the scope 
of work and implementation arrangements with the Government. The Mission held detailed 
discussions  with  the  National  Development  Planning  Agency  (BAPPENAS),  Ministry  of 
Agriculture (MOA), and Ministry of Finance (MOF), as well as other relevant agencies, on the 
rationale, objectives, scope, cost estimates, implementation arrangements, and financing plan 
for the TA. The Mission also met with representatives of the Food and Agriculture Organization 
(FAO)  and  other  external  funding  agencies,  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs),  and 
stakeholders to discuss the TA. It is in line with the Government's priorities and anticipated 
initiatives, as well as with the strategic priorities of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in 
Indonesia. The TA is included in ADB's 2003 country strategy and program for Indonesia.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  About 24 million hectares (ha), 19% of Indonesia’s land area, is under agriculture. Of 
this, estate crops—including rubber, oil palm, coconut, cocoa, coffee, tea, sugar cane, cotton, 
tobacco, cloves, pepper, and other minor crops—are grown on almost 15 million ha and provide 
a substantial portion of income to more than 13 million households. Estate crops account for 
about 50% of agricultural export earnings and 18% of non-oil exports. In 2002 estate crops 
generated foreign exchange earnings of more than $3 billion. Indonesia is the second largest 
producer of rubber after Thailand, and of oil palm after Malaysia. 
 
3.  Over  the  last  25  years  public  and  private  investment  in  smallholder  tree-crop2 
development has been high. The Government has borrowed $3.2 billion from external sources 
and mobilized an equivalent level of domestic resources in the sector, much of which has 
supported smallholder development and created substantial income-generating assets for small 
farmers in the form of trees. Investment has also been large in associated processing facilities 
and in a wide variety of up- and downstream activities that have created many jobs and 
contribute substantially to household incomes, the national economy, and exports.  
 
4.  Since 1985 ADB has provided 18 loans amounting to $935 million to the tree-crop 
sector. Many ADB-financed projects in the environment, forestry, and natural resources sectors 
have  included  components  to  reduce  rural  poverty  and  enhance  income.  Other  external 
agencies funding tree-crop sector projects include the World Bank, International Fund for 
Agricultural Development, and Japan Bank for International Cooperation. A recent sector study3 
and project completion report4 concluded that investments have, for the most part, substantially 
increased the incomes and well-being of smallholders, providing secure incomes, lifting families 
out of poverty, and securing livelihoods for several decades to come. However, productivity in 
the smallholder tree-crop sector remains well below potential, compared not only with research

station  results,  but  also  with  the  performance  of  neighboring  countries.  For  example,  the 
smallholder yield of rubber is 0.65 ton (t)/ha, compared to 1.50–2.00 t/ha in Thailand. For palm 
oil, smallholder yield is 2.5 t crude palm oil (cpo)/ha, compared to 6.0 t cpo/ha in Malaysia. Apart 
from low productivity, many tree-crop products suffer from low quality and inefficient processing 
and marketing. Products such as coffee and cocoa also face export restrictions due to sanitary 
and disease factors, which further reduce the farm-gate price. The main factors causing low 
productivity  of  smallholder  tree  crops  are  old  age  of  trees  (rubber,  coconut,  coffee,  tea); 
genetically low-yielding planting materials (rubber, coconut, coffee, cashew, tea); low use of 
inputs; and poor crop maintenance. 
 
5.  Past assistance has focused on physical development of plantations, infrastructure, and 
processing facilities rather than building institutional capacity and empowering farmers. Lessons 
learned indicate that mallholders do not readily adopt new technologies and lack information on 
all aspects of production, processing, and marketing. Limited human resources and facilities, 
exacerbated  under  decentralization,  constrain  extension  services  to  smallholders. 
Dissemination of research findings and transfer of technology should be improved to encourage 
farmers to adopt new technologies, especially to improve and distribute planting materials to 
assure higher productivity. Older trees should be replanted, and smallholders helped to adopt 
and  implement  new  technologies,  improve  cultural  practices,  and  enhance  marketing 
opportunities.  Markets  should  be  allowed  to  function  freely,  and  the  interaction  among 
government, the private sector, and smallholders should be strengthened.  
 
6.  Since 2002 the Directorate General of Estate Crops and Production (DGECP) has been 
promoting  a  “new  paradigm,”  establishing  Tree-Crop  Industry  Stakeholder  Development 
Program (KIMBUN)5 areas to bring the benefits of downstream development to smallholder 
farmers.  The  pilot-scale  Farmer  Empowerment  Program,  developed  under  the  TA  for 
Sustainable Management Systems for Tree Crops (see footnote 3) supports institution building 
of public sector institutions that help smallholders, focusing on developing viable, self-help 
community-based organizations of smallholder farmers to interface with regional government 
agencies and the private sector. MOA recently adopted this model for its farmer empowerment 
programs. The TA sector study proposes a major, continuing role for the Government in 
developing smallholder tree crops. Production, exports, and tax revenue must be increased; 
poverty reduced in a sustainable manner; and rural economies made less vulnerable to shocks. 
Sustainable mechanisms must be encouraged to finance research, promotion, and replanting. 
The Government’s core functions are facilitator, stimulator, and regulator, although success will 
require a change in the way government institutions operate and allocate budgets, taking 
account  of  devolution  of  responsibilities  to  the  regions.  While  the  smallholder  credit 
requirements should be met by the domestic financial institutions, public sector investments will 
still be required for infrastructure and technology development, and capacity building. 
 
7.  ADB  assistance  to  rural  development  is  increasingly  concentrating  on  the  poorest 
regions  to  help  strengthen  regional  government  capacities  to  aid  agricultural  and  rural 
development. An ADB-financed agriculture and rural development strategy study6 that started in 
June 2003 to review domestic policies and study the responses to the international trade policy 
environment  in  the  agricultural  sector  will  support  TA  preparation  and  implementation. 
Continued public sector investment is considered important to restructure support services for 
the  smallholder  sector  under  decentralization;  finance  replanting  of  aging  trees;  promote

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output  
8.  The purpose of the TA is to prepare an investment project with the primary goals of 
increasing the contribution of tree crops to the national economy and reducing poverty of 
smallholders by increasing their incomes. The TA study will (i) identify and analyze sectoral 
issues and constraints; (ii) identify alternative intervention options; (iii) provide information to 
compare  and  choose  among  options,  assessing  their  likely  impacts;  and  (iv)  prepare  an 
investment project. 
 
9.  The investment project will aim to increase the incomes of smallholder tree-crop farmers 
and to remove constraints on tree-crop subsector productivity. The project will improve support 
and  regulatory  services,  targeting  the  poor,  through  district-level  interventions.  Specific 
objectives  include  (i)  restructuring  of  support  services  for  the  smallholder  subsector;  (ii) 
promotion of diversified and sustainable farming systems among small tree-crop farmers; and 
(iii) provision of infrastructure to encourage the development of integrated tree-crop production, 
marketing,  processing,  and  manufacturing,  through  private  sector  investment,  state-owned 
enterprises, and cooperatives.  
 
10.  Specific TA outputs will (i) prepare an investment project to achieve the stated objectives 
consistent with Ministerial Decree (KEPMEN) 35/2003 and other regulations relevant to fund 
channeling, (ii) prepare districts (particularly local government agencies and local parliaments) 
and communities to participate in the investment project, and (iii) establish nurseries to provide 
replanting materials. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities  
11.  The  investment  project  will  focus  on  perennial  tree  crops.  Historically,  ADB  has 
supported rubber, oil palm, cashews, cocoa, coconut, tea, and coffee, and this project will aim to 
enhance the productivity of previous investments. The Government has requested expansion of 
the range of crops to include pepper and other tree crops. The project will take a farming 
systems  approach7  rather  than  a  commodity-based  approach  to  identify  appropriate 
interventions, recognizing that the technology and opportunities are different for each tree crop 
and location. For example, replanting is important for rubber and coconut; rehabilitation for 
coffee and tea; and intensification for oil palm, cocoa, cashew, and pepper. Income-enhancing 
activities such as intercropping during replanting and diversification will be analyzed. 
 
12.  During the TA’s inception stage, target districts will be identified using a geographic 
information system-based analysis of data on poverty, existence and distribution of smallholder 
tree crops, ethnic representation, fiscal condition of the districts, and consideration of ADB’s 
geographic focus. Approximately 30 districts are expected to be included under the project, 
distributed in four of the major island groups. 
 
                                                 
7  A farming systems approach considers the whole farm rather than individual elements, recognizing that the system 
is driven as much by the overall welfare of farming households as by yield and profitability. The approach also 
recognizes the influence of the external environmental and political, economic, institutional, and social factors.

4      
     
     
13.  The next phase of the TA will review policy, legislation, regulations, and lessons learned. 
Studies will assess: (i) constraints on and opportunities for production, processing, marketing, 
and infrastructure; (ii) farmer empowerment needs; and (iii) skills, financial capacity, training, 
and staffing needs of regional administrations and NGOs to provide services for tree-crop 
farmers. Studies will also identify mechanisms to finance research, promotion, and replanting; 
assess working and investment capital requirements of smallholders and identify options and 
sources of credit; propose selection criteria and processes for inclusion of smallholders; and 
identify target farmer groups.  
 
14.  The final stage of the TA will prepare a detailed plan of activities, including costs and 
implementation  arrangements,  for  each  district  in  consultation  with  district  government 
agencies, and prepare a detailed feasibility study for the investment project. 
 
15.  The feasibility study will consider the many complex and diverse issues that affect the 
tree-crop sector: (i) economic factors such as (a) overall industry structure and functioning; (b) 
farm  household  and  estate  worker  resources  and  livelihoods;  (c)  changing  domestic  and 
international prices and behavioral responses of producers, processors, traders, and buyers; 
and  (d)  public  and  market-related  institutions;  (ii)  industry  and  government  incentives  to 
encourage smallholders to invest in tree crops, recognizing their long gestation period; (iii) 
mechanisms  to  fund  commodity  research,  promotion,  and  replanting;  (iv)  improvement  of 
collection, processing, and marketing efficiency; and (v) the role of the private sector and 
commodity associations in improving commodity performance. 
 
16.  Districts will help prepare the project through regional-  and  district-level workshops 
involving  district  government  agencies  and  local  communities.  Local  stakeholders  will  be 
consulted throughout the process, aiming to result in a letter of commitment by the district 
government to participate in the project, provide counterpart budgets, and comply with national 
government  financing  requirements.  To  prepare  for  early  implementation  of  replanting 
programs, the TA will also establish nurseries in strategic locations to form the basis for 
distributing improved planting material. A project framework for the TA is in Appendix 1. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1.443 million equivalent, of which $483,000 is 
the foreign exchange cost and $960,000 equivalent the local currency cost. The Government 
has requested ADB to finance $800,000 equivalent, consisting of $338,000 in foreign exchange 
costs and $462,000 equivalent of the local currency costs. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis from the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The Investment 
Centre of FAO (FAO-IC) will finance $343,000 equivalent on a grant basis.8 The Government 
will finance the remaining $300,000 equivalent of the local currency costs, and has assured the 
availability of counterpart services and facilities by the expected commencement date of the TA. 
Detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 2. The Government has been advised that approval of 
the TA does not commit ADB to financing any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  The DGECP of MOA will be the Executing Agency for the TA. DGECP will work in close 
cooperation with MOA’s Directorates of Agricultural Facilities (DGAF) and Agricultural Product

Processing and Marketing Development (DGAPPMD), MOF, and BAPPENAS. DGECP will 
appoint a project manager and appropriate counterparts for day-to-day TA coordination under 
the direct supervision of the director general of DGECP. Its counterparts will work closely with 
the  consultants  and  be  responsible  for  liaison  with  regional  governments  in  each  target 
province, especially provision of local counterparts and arrangement of field trips. DGECP will 
provide office accommodation and logistical support for the TA study, and adequate budgetary 
support for staff travel and per diem. DGECP will coordinate and collaborate with external 
agencies and stakeholders, including national and international forestry and tree-crop research 
institutions, industry associations, and NGOs. The TA will be implemented in a fully participatory 
manner, including by holding stakeholder workshops to discuss the approach with key central, 
provincial and district agencies; target communities (including ethnic groups); external agencies; 
NGOs; research organizations; and other stakeholders The summary initial poverty and social 
analysis is in Appendix 3. 
 
19.  A TA steering committee (TASC), chaired by a senior officer in DGECP, and comprising 
senior representatives from BAPPENAS, DGAF, DGAPPMD, MOF, and other relevant agencies 
and stakeholders, will be established and meet monthly to review the progress, and guide TA 
direction and outputs, including selection of target districts. TASC will invite stakeholder inputs 
by involving key individuals, NGOs, and associations representing indigenous peoples, target 
districts, and the private sector.  
 
20.  ADB and FAO-IC will implement the TA in accordance with the long-standing working 
arrangements between FAO and ADB (see footnote 8). FAO-IC has an institutional advantage 
and is well qualified through its wide experience in preparing development projects, worldwide 
expertise in agriculture, and, particularly, ongoing implementation of the TA for Sustainable 
Management Systems for Tree Crops (footnote 3).  Consultants or experts hired by FAO-IC will 
be  engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  or  other 
arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants. Participation of 
FAO-IC staff and consultants will be subject to technical clearance by ADB. Goods will be 
procured in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement, for handover to DGECP on TA 
completion. 
 
21.  The  TA  consulting  team  will  comprise  7  international  and  12  domestic  specialists. 
Expertise will be required in tree-crop agronomy and research, economics, finance and credit, 
community development, international trade and marketing, industry and processing, policy and 
institutions, environment, infrastructure, land titling, monitoring and evaluation, and geographic 
and management information systems. In total, 102 person-months (21 international and 81 
domestic) input will be required. The FAO-IC team leader will work full-time in Indonesia for the 
duration of the TA study. The outline terms of reference for the TA and person-months of 
specialist inputs are in Appendix 4. 
 
22.  The TA is expected to commence in January 2004 and be completed in September 
2004. An inception report will be prepared in the 6th week, an interim report in the 20th week, 
and a draft final report in the 34th week. Tripartite meetings between the Government, FAO-IC, 
and ADB will be held within 2 weeks of submission of the reports to discuss the findings. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  Indonesia  for  preparing  the  Productivity  Enhancement  for  Tree  Crops 
Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

SUMMARY INITIAL POVERTY AND SOCIAL ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis 
Sector identified as a national priority in country  Sector identified as a national priority in country poverty  
poverty analysis? YES  partnership agreement? YES 
 
Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Indonesia: 
Poverty is high in rural Indonesia, where an estimated 20.2% of the population lives below the poverty line, 
compared with 15.1% in urban areas (1999). Many communities, particularly smallholder tree-crop farmers, are 
included in this category. The project goals are to increase the contribution of tree crops to the national economy 
and to reduce poverty levels by increasing farmer incomes. The project purposes are to increase the incomes of 
smallholder tree-crop farmers and to remove constraints on tree-crop subsector productivity by promoting 
increased on-farm productivity and improving farm incomes, and facilitating the marketing of tree-crop commodities 
by smallholder farmers. The project will empower farmers and make institutional arrangements for government and 
nongovernment support to smallholder tree-crop farmers.  
 
B.  Poverty Analysis        Proposed Classification: Poverty Intervention 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
During the initial phase of the project preparatory technical assistance (TA), the consultants will compile data on 
poverty and smallholder tree crops throughout Indonesia, using geographic information system mapping techniques 
to link the information for use in selecting target provinces, districts, and communities, and to provide a baseline 
database for subsequent project monitoring. The consultants will also review and document ongoing and completed 
tree-crop projects to identify successful schemes, and then identify needs and interventions to prepare the investment 
project. 
 
A poverty and social analysis will be undertaken to estimate the expected impact of project interventions on poor 
communities, other stakeholders (including intermediaries and nongovernment organizations, and national and local 
governments. The analysis will examine the distribution of project costs and benefits, in financial and economic 
terms, allocated to various stakeholders, assess the social impact, and estimate the distribution of project effects to 
the poor to determine the poverty impact, as outlined in ADB’s Handbook for Integrating Poverty Impact Assessment 
in the Economic Analysis of Projects and ADB’s Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis. 
 
C.  Participation Process 
Stakeholder analysis: During the review of ongoing and completed tree-crop projects, and preparation of districts to 
participate in the project, the consultants will identify and consult with a cross-section of stakeholders to determine 
their roles, functions, and needs and to understand supply chains to markets for tree-crop commodities. The outcome 
of this analysis will form the basis to identify mechanisms and interventions for target districts to be included under 
the project.  
 
Participation strategy required: The TA will be implemented in a fully participatory manner, and the consultants will 
organize participatory stakeholder workshops during TA implementation at the national, island-group, and district 
levels to discuss the approach and findings with key central, provincial, and district agencies; representatives of 
target communities; external agencies; NGOs; research organizations; and other interested parties. The TA will 
prepare districts (particularly local administrations and local parliaments) to participate in the investment project in 
accordance with Ministerial Decree (KEPMEN) 35/2003.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  General 
 
1.  The TA consulting team, to be assembled by the Investment Centre of the Food and 
Agricultural Organization (FAO-IC), consisting of 7 international and 12 domestic consultants, 
will  work  in  close  collaboration  with  the  Directorate  General  of  Estate  Crops  Production 
(DGECP) of the Ministry of Agriculture (MOA). The team will also work with other directorates 
within MOA, Ministry of Finance, National Planning Agency (BAPPENAS) and other national 
agencies, and with provincial and district governments and agencies in target areas, to prepare 
the investment project. 
 
2.  The TA will be implemented in a fully participatory manner, involving all agencies and 
beneficiaries.  The  TA  team  will  organize  one  national  workshop  and  several  subsequent 
regional workshops to discuss the approach and options for the design of the project with key 
national, provincial, and district agencies. These workshops will also allow representatives of 
target  communities,  external  and  nongovernmental  agencies,  and  research  and  industry 
organizations to help design and prepare the project. The team will also organize a final 
workshop to disseminate the TA recommendations and reach an agreement on all aspects of 
the project with the agencies involved in its implementation. 
 
3.  The TA inception phase will concentrate on preparing an overview of smallholder tree-
crop production and poverty, establishing selection criteria, and selecting districts to be included 
in the project. Then detailed preparation of project activities for each district will begin. The 
interim phase will determine and reach agreement on the policy and long-term objectives of 
national and local government assistance to smallholder tree-crop farmers. During the final 
phase,  detailed  district-level  preparation  and  analysis  will  be  completed  for  each  district, 
including  letters  of  commitment  from  district  governments  to  participate  in  the  project. 
Stakeholders will be prepared and trained to implement of the project. National project activities 
will also be identified. A feasibility report for the project will be prepared in a format suitable for 
appraisal  of  the  project  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB), containing the required 
analyses and assessments.  
 
4.  Following each TA phase, a report will be prepared for discussion at tripartite meetings 
between the Government, FAO-IC, and ADB. An inception report will be prepared in the 6th 
week, an interim report in the 20th week, and a draft final report in the 34th week. Tripartite 
meetings will be held within 2 weeks of submission of the reports to discuss the findings. The 
TA team will submit 10 printed copies of the inception, interim, and draft final reports, and 20 
printed copies of the final report. The executive summary of each report will be prepared in 
Bahasa Indonesia and an electronic copy of the full report on compact disc (CD-ROM) will be 
provided to each participating province and district.  
 
B.  Detailed Activities 
5.  The activities to be completed under the TA will include the following tasks: 
 
6.  Analyze the Distribution and Productivity of the Smallholder Tree-Crop Subsector 
by  Commodity.  Compile  information  on  smallholder  production,  incomes,  and  poverty  to 
identify the social, agricultural, economic, cultural, and historical factors that have contributed to 
the present situation.

12  Appendix 4 
 
7.  Select Target Districts Based on Poverty, Potential, Local Government Priorities, 
and Geographical Focus. Map physical areas and productivity (current and potential) for the 
main tree crops, processing capacity and marketing channels, social and socioeconomic data, 
fiscal position of the district governments, and other selection criteria. Based on data analysis, 
prepare a list of potential districts. Assess their willingness and capacity to meet conditions of 
national  grants  and  loans,  then  select  districts  for  inclusion  in  the  project.  Consider  the 
implications of ADB’s geographic focus for support to Indonesia. 
 
8.  Engage  in  Dialogue  with  Selected  Districts.  Undertake  an  initial  island-group 
workshop and district-level workshops involving district government and agencies and local 
communities. Establish four working groups in a central location in each island group to work 
directly with district governments and agencies to identify communities to participate in the 
project, and to identify and prepare a program of activities for inclusion. Identify implementation 
responsibilities for these activities, and estimate the costs involved to determine the counterpart 
financing requirement from district sources under Ministerial Decree (KEPMEN) 35/2003.  
 
9.  Assess  Capacity  and  Needs  of  National  and  District  Administrations  and 
Nongovernment  Organizations  (NGOs). Determine the skills, experience, and budgetary 
capacity of district government agencies to provide services for tree-crop farmers in the selected 
districts, and identify the training and staffing requirements to redirect and improve service 
delivery. Particular attention will be paid to information technology requirements and systems. 
Analyze these aspects in relation to national government agencies. Review the presence and 
capacity of NGOs in the targeted district to support government initiatives to improve the 
livelihoods of smallholder tree-crop farmers. Design and cost a program of support to build the 
capacity of these agencies and organizations to be included in the project. 
 
10.  Analyze Existing Policy, Legislation, and Regulations. Study economic, policy, and 
sector factors such as overall industry structure and conduct; farm household and estate worker 
resource and livelihood situations; changing domestic and international price situation and the 
behavioral response of producers, processors, traders, and buyers; and the underpinning public 
and  market-related  institutional  situation.  Systematically  study  these  issues  to  identify  the 
market and institutional factors that affect access to employment and wages in the industry, 
markets and input and output prices, assets such as land and credit and their effect on 
production possibility and incentives, and support services, and thus producers’ response to the 
present situation and industry performance in general. Identify incentives to develop smallholder 
tree  crops,  determine  the  impact  of  regulatory  constraints,  and  prepare  associated 
recommendations. 
 
11.  Review  and  Document  Existing  and  Completed  Government  and  Externally 
Assisted Projects to Identify Lessons Learned. Include schemes of the Project Management 
Unit (PMU) and Nucleus Estate and Smallholder (NES) type developed over the past 20 years, 
and  a  review  of  the  Tree  Crops  Industry  Stakeholder  Development  Program  (KIMBUN) 
initiatives  being  supported  by  DGECP.  Compile  an  overview  of  the  lessons  learned  from 
experience  of  tree-crop  projects  supported  by  external  agencies  in  Indonesia  and  similar 
countries.  
 
12.  Identify Successful Assistance Opportunities for Smallholder Tree-Crop Farmers. 
Develop  a  set  of  design  elements  that  would  form  a  best  practice  for  major  tree-crop 
commodities. Review the implications of diversification and conversion using a farming-systems

Appendix 4  13 
approach.  Review  the  interaction  of  smallholders  with  the  private  sector,  and  identify 
opportunities for enhanced private-sector participation for smallholders. 
 
13.  Assess Possible Mechanisms to Finance Research, Promotion, and Replanting. 
Review the experience of schemes in Indonesia and comparable countries in financing these 
activities. Examine issues and options for national and local governments in implementing such 
schemes. 
 
14.  Identify  Capacities  and  Priorities  for  Research  in  Technology  and  Farming 
Systems. Review the programs and resources of the main commodity research institutes, and 
the impact of the research programs in relation to overcoming technical production constraints. 
Review processing technology research, including processing of by-products and varying scales 
of processing capacity, and research into farming and livelihood systems for communities and 
households  where  trees  contribute  a  significant  part  of  household  income.  Pay  particular 
attention to small-scale technology packages suitable for smallholders. Design and cost a 
research program for inclusion in the project. 
 
15.  Assess Constraints on and Opportunities in Processing and Marketing. Review 
international and local dynamics for tree-crop commodities, particularly relationships between 
production and processing capacity, and local and international supply and demand for these 
commodities. Review and update the report on marketing and processing of oil palm and rubber 
prepared  under  TA  for  Sustainable  Management  Systems  for  Tree  Crops  Development.1 
Prepare a similar analysis for other major tree-crop commodities. Prepare a project component 
to remove regulatory, institutional, and technical constraints on marketing and processing of 
commodities.  
 
16.  Social, Poverty and Environmental Analysis.  Analyse  expected  impact  of  project 
interventions on poor communities, indigenous peoples, gender, involuntary re-settlement, other 
stakeholders (including intermediaries and nongovernment organizations, national and local 
governments. Examine the distribution of project costs and benefits, in financial and economic 
terms, allocated to various stakeholders, assess the social impact, and estimate the distribution 
of project effects to the poor to determine the poverty impact. Also assess the expected impact 
of the proposed project interventions on the environment.2 
 
17.  Empower Farmers. Assess the local institutional setting in the project districts. Assess 
the capacities and needs of farmers in production and marketing group activities. Identify and 
cost  a  process  to  empower  farmer-  and  community-based  organizations.  Familiarize 
beneficiaries in districts with the project approach to create awareness of and readiness for a 
farmer empowerment program. 
 
18.  Initiate Production of Planting Materials for the Investment Program. Establish 
nurseries in strategic locations to form the basis for distribution of improved planting material. 
Design the management and distribution systems for improved planting material for inclusion as 
a project component.

19.  Assess Working and Investment Capital Requirements of Smallholders to Improve 
Productivity, and Identify Options and Sources of Credit. Assess the financial requirement 
of smallholder farmers in tree-crop production, especially those associated with replanting with 
improved  genetic  materials.  Examine  household  cash  requirements  during  replanting  and 
include  investment  and  working  capital  requirements  of  alternative  intensification  and 
diversification options available to farmers. Assess the total capital requirements for individual 
districts given the options likely to be applied by farmers when replanting or changing farming 
systems. Identify credit needs of smallholders, review previous smallholder credit schemes, and 
identify appropriate options, sources and mechanisms for providing credit to smallholders. 
 
20.  Assess  Infrastructure  Constraints.  Assess  the  current  state  of  infrastructure, 
particularly farm access roads, in the individual districts. Estimate the extent and cost of 
establishing a satisfactory harvest road system for tree-crop areas in the selected districts. 
Identify  responsibilities  and  cost-recovery  mechanisms  for  regular  maintenance  of  roads. 
Design and cost a program of infrastructure improvement for each district. 
 
21.  Propose  Selection  Criteria  and  Processes  for  Inclusion  of  Smallholders,  and 
Identify Target Farmer Groups. Consider such aspects as willingness of local administrations 
and communities to participate, agricultural potential for increased productivity, and potential for 
incremental production from the area to be sold and/or processed. 
 
22.  Prepare a Detailed Costed Plan of Activities for Each District in Consultation with 
District Government Agencies.  Activities and investments will be identified on the basis of 
technical, social, institutional, economic, financial, and environmental feasibility. Consultation 
and agreement with district government agencies will be conducted throughout the process, 
resulting in (i) a letter of commitment from the district government to participate in the project 
and comply with any financing requirements under KEPMEN 35/2003, and (ii) a project proposal 
for submission to the appraisal team established under KEPMEN 35/2003. 
 
23.  Prepare a Detailed Investment Project Feasibility Report and Project Framework. 
Include the following: 
 
(i)  details of the location of project activities (by village, subdistrict, district, province) 
including  details  on  poverty  status,3  willingness  of  local  communities  to 
participate,  and  institutional  capacity  of  the  target  communities  and  local 
government agencies; 
(ii)  an assessment of the impact on indigenous people, any involuntary resettlement, 
and gender issues;4  
(iii)  a logical framework for the project, including a set of monitorable, quantifiable, 
and  time-bound  indicators  and  targets;  a  detailed  description  of  proposed 
activities; cost estimates (foreign exchange and local currency costs); financing 
plan  (including  possible  cofinancing  from  other  agencies);  and  counterpart 
financing  (including  an  assessment  of  on-lending  issues  under  KEPMEN 
35/2003);5  
                                                 
3  As outlined in ADB’s Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis.

on Gender and Development.  
5  Prepared using COSTAB software.

(v)  institutional and financial arrangements for implementation, including a detailed 
assessment of organizational arrangements, and channeling mechanisms for

(vi)  an  environmental  assessment  (clearly  indicating  potential  social  and
